laboratory_examinations.findings: Random serum GH levels were 138 ng/ml, elevated compared to normal range.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Elevated GH levels persisted despite interventions, with a decrease to normal levels after surgical removal of pituitary gland.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Serum PRL levels were 520–795 ng/ml, elevated compared to normal range (0–11 ng/ml).
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: PRL levels persisted elevated until after surgery, when they decreased to low normal levels (6 ng/ml).

laboratory_examinations.findings: GH levels increased in response to the insulin challenge; GH levels reached up to 200 ng/ml.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: GH did not suppress during the oral glucose suppression test.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Serum IGF-I ranged from 300–350 ng/ml, elevated compared to normal range.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Normal age-adjusted levels reached by postoperative day 3.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Serum GHRH levels ranged from 21 to 23 pg/ml, below the reference range (5–18 pg/ml).
GH decreased to 1.6 ng/ml, within the normal range.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Rapid decline to low normal levels was observed by the first postoperative day.

laboratory_examinations.findings: PRL decreased to 6 ng/ml, within the low normal range.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: A rapid decline to low normal levels occurred by the first postoperative day.

laboratory_examinations.findings: MRI revealed a homogeneously enlarged pituitary gland with no evidence of a tumor.
Histopathology showed diffuse hyperplasia of mammosomatotrophs without evidence of adenoma.
